Content.description: Do not hype a study by listing authors' qualifications.
Content.reference: In general, do not hype a study by listing the names, credentials, institutions, or other 'qualifications' of their authors.

Content.description: Focus article prose on what a cited study says about the gene or protein.
Content.reference: Article prose should focus on what a cited study says about the structure, function, clinical significance, etc. of the gene or protein, not what the gene or protein says about a particular study or the research group who conducted that study.

Content.description: Mention notable contributions and discoveries in the history section.
Content.reference: Particularly notable contributions along with who made the discovery however should be mentioned in the discovery/history section.

Content.description: Use the recommended UniProt protein name as the article name if it is relatively short.
Content.reference: If relatively short, the recommended UniProt protein name should be used as the article name.
Content.when: When the UniProt name is relatively short

Content.description: Use a protein acronym or official HUGO gene symbol with '(gene)' if the protein name is verbose.
Content.reference: If the protein name is verbose, either a widely used protein acronym or the official HUGO gene symbol, followed by '(gene)' if necessary to disambiguate.
Content.when: When the UniProt name is verbose

Content.description: Include the taxon in the title for viral protein articles.
Content.reference: If the article is about a viral protein, it is recommended to include the taxon in the title.

Content.description: Do not consider parenthesized disambiguation as unnecessary.
Content.reference: A parenthesized term added to disambiguate common symbols does not constitute unnecessary disambiguation even when it is the only article with such a name.

Content.description: Use HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee abbreviations in italic font.
Content.reference: The abbreviations of genes are according to HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee and written in ''italic'' font style.

Content.description: Prefer abbreviations over full gene names.
Content.reference: It is recommended that abbreviations instead of the full name are used.

Content.description: Write human gene names in all capitals.
Content.reference: Human gene names are written in capitals, for example 'ALDOA', 'INS', etc.

Content.description: Capitalize only the initial letter for orthologs in other species.
Content.reference: For orthologs of human genes in other species, only the initial letter is capitalised, for example mouse 'Aldoa', bovine 'Ins', etc.
Content.when: When referring to orthologs in other species

Content.description: Use recommended usages for gene symbols.
Content.reference: The following usages of gene symbols are recommended: the ALDOA gene is regulated..., the rat gene for Aldoa is regulated... or ''ALDOA'' is regulated...

Content.description: Avoid using redundant phrasing for gene symbols.
Content.reference: the gene ''ALDOA'' is regulated since it is redundant.

Content.description: Maintain standard format for diagrams where possible.
Content.reference: Where possible, diagrams should keep to a standard format.

Content.description: Suggest expansions to standardized formatting if diagram guide is insufficient.
Content.reference: If the diagram guide does not give sufficient guidance on the style for the images in an article, consider suggesting expansions to the standardised formatting.

Content.description: Include one or more appropriate infoboxes at the top of each article.
Content.reference: One or more of the following infoboxes as appropriate should be included at the top of each article:

Content.description: Add enzyme infobox if only one human paralog is assigned to an EC number.
Content.reference: If there is only one human paralog assigned to a given EC number..., then in addition to a protein infobox, it may be appropriate to also add the corresponding enzyme infobox.
Content.when: When one human paralog is assigned to an EC number

Content.description: Include a protein family infobox if only one human paralog is assigned to a Pfam family.
Content.reference: Likewise, if there is only one human paralog that has been assigned to Pfam family, then including a protein family infobox may also be appropriate.
Content.when: When one human paralog is assigned to a Pfam family

Content.description: Limit the number of infoboxes and place less useful ones in a table section at the end.
Content.reference: There exist some cases where a large number of infoboxes may apply to an article. You may put less useful ones in a section at the end, laid side-by-side with a table.

Content.description: Include the lead section before the first headline.
Content.reference: The lead section is defined as 'the section before the first headline. The table of contents, if displayed, appears between the lead section and the first headline.'

Content.description: Define the scope of the article in the first sentence of the lead.
Content.reference: The first sentence of the lead should define what the scope of the article is.

Content.description: Provide specific gene information without unnecessary repetition from the infobox.
Content.reference: Specific information about the gene... should not be unnecessarily repeated in this section unless especially notable.
Content.when: When information is already in the infobox

Content.description: Provide specific protein information without unnecessary repetition from the infobox.
Content.reference: Specific information about the protein... should not be unnecessarily repeated unless especially notable.
Content.when: When information is already in the infobox

Content.description: Include 'Species, tissue, and subcellular distribution' as an optional section.
Content.reference: Optional section that concisely describes what species this gene is expressed..., what tissue the protein is expressed, and which subcellular compartments or organelles the protein is found...

Content.description: Include a 'Function' section to describe the protein's function.
Content.reference: Describe the function of the transcribed protein.

Content.description: Include 'Interactions' as an optional section listing protein interactions.
Content.reference: Optional section that lists proteins that the protein that is the subject of the article is known to interact with.

Content.description: Include 'Clinical significance' section listing related diseases or conditions.
Content.reference: List diseases or conditions that are a result of a mutation in the gene or a deficiency or excess of the expressed protein.

Content.description: Do not mention research groups or institutions directly in the article text.
Content.reference: In general, it is not appropriate to mention the research group or institution that conducted a study directly in the text of the article.

Content.description: List names of key discoverers in the history section.
Content.reference: However it is appropriate to list the names of those who made key discoveries concerning the gene or protein in this section.

Content.description: Link the article to the appropriate Wikidata item based on the first sentence of the lead.
Content.reference: The Wikipedia article should be linked to a Wikidata item of the entity first mentioned in the first sentence of the lead section...

Content.description: Use inline citations densely with <ref> tags or parenthetical citations.
Content.reference: MCB articles should be relatively dense with inline citations, using either <ref> tags (footnotes) or parenthetical citations.

Content.description: Do not use non-specific general references in the References section.
Content.reference: It is not acceptable to write substantial amounts of prose and then add your textbook to the References section as a non-specific or general reference.

Content.description: Maintain consistent citation formatting within an article.
Content.reference: There is no standard for formatting citations on Wikipedia, but the format should be consistent within any one article.

Content.description: Prefer using citation templates for better control over presentation.
Content.reference: Some editors prefer to use citation templates such as {{Cite journal}}, {{Cite book}}, etc.

Content.description: Supply hyperlinks in citations when available.
Content.reference: In addition to the standard citation text, it is useful to supply hyperlinks...

Content.description: Avoid adding 'Retrieved on' dates for convenience links to online journals.
Content.reference: Do not add a 'Retrieved on' date for convenience links to online editions of paper journals...
Content.when: When linking to online editions of paper journals

Content.description: Link articles about related proteins using navigation boxes.
Content.reference: Articles about related proteins may be cross linked by including one or more navigation boxes as appropriate.

Content.description: Add each article to at least one appropriate category.
Content.reference: Every Wikipedia article should be added to at least one category.

Formatting.description: Maintain standard format for diagrams where possible.
Formatting.reference: Where possible, diagrams should keep to a standard format.

Formatting.description: Suggest expansions to standardized formatting if diagram guide is insufficient.
Formatting.reference: If the diagram guide does not give sufficient guidance on the style for the images in an article, consider suggesting expansions to the standardised formatting.
